keyText:
holy.

important in a religion, or used in worship.

the holy book of the Sikhs

applaud.

to show that you enjoyed someone’s performance, speech, etc. by hitting the palms of your hands together.

They have been applauded for their humanitarian work in Ethiopia.

upcoming.

an upcoming event will happen soon.

the upcoming elections

convention.

a meeting that a lot of people belonging to a particular profession or organization go to in order to discuss things.

Chicago was chosen as the site for an international crime convention.

dissolve.

if a solid substance dissolves in a liquid, it is mixed into the liquid so that it becomes included in it.

dissolve in: salt dissolves in water

simultaneous.

happening or done at the same time.

In simultaneous announcements, the two men resigned from their jobs.

evaluate.

to think carefully about something before making a judgment about its value, importance, or quality.

The performance of each employee is evaluated once a year.

compliment.

something nice that you say to praise someone.

It is a compliment to be compared to her.

campaign.

a series of things that a politician or political party does to try to win an election.

It is alleged that the party used illegal methods to finance its campaign.

exaggerated.

describing something in a way that makes it seem better, worse, larger, more important, etc. than it really is.

exaggerated claims about the drug’s benefits

withdraw.

to take something back, or to stop providing something.

The bus service in many rural areas has been withdrawn.

exhibit.

to put something interesting in a museum or other public place so that people can go look at it.

His work will be exhibited in Moscow later this year.

foresee.

to see or know something that will happen in the future.

Who could have foreseen such problems?

gesture.

a movement that communicates a feeling or instruction.

a helpless/impatient/dramatic gesture

primitive.

at a very simple stage of development, before modern technology.

a primitive society/tribe

privilege.

a special benefit that is available only to a particular person or group.

Cheap air travel is one of the privileges of working for the airline.

feminine.

having qualities that are traditionally considered to be typical of women, for example being gentle and delicate.

The look this year is soft and feminine.

scope.

the things that a particular activity, organization, subject, etc. deals with.

in scope: The new law is limited in scope.

preliminary.

coming before the main or most important part of something.

a preliminary hearing/discussion/analysis/proposal/agreement

consumption.

the process of eating, drinking, or smoking something.

fit/unfit for human consumption: Most of the meat was unfit for human consumption.

misfortune.

bad luck.

The family was plagued by misfortune.

attorney.

.

hazard.

something that could be dangerous or could cause damage or accidents.

One of the most widespread natural hazards is flooding.

rival.

a person, team, or business that competes with another.

The Dallas Cowboys beat their rivals 20–10.

vertical.

standing, pointing, or moving straight up. Something that is horizontal is parallel to the ground or its base.

vertical lines

insert.

to put something into something else, or into a hole or space.

insert something into/in something: Insert the plug into the earphone socket.

deteriorate.

to become worse.

The weather deteriorated rapidly so the game was abandoned.

diminish.

to become less.

Her enthusiasm was by now fast diminishing.

nutritious.

nutritious foods provide the substances that people need in order to be healthy.

a nutritious meal

obscure.

not known about, or not well known.

Details of this period of Shakespeare’s life remain obscure.

downward.

toward a lower place or level.

He looked downward.

refresh.

to make you feel that you have more energy again, especially when you are tired or hot.

Refresh your face with some cologne.

edible.

food that is edible is safe or good enough to eat.

edible mushrooms

asset.

something such as money or property that a person or company owns.

The business has assets totaling $5.1 million.

technician.

someone with technical training whose job involves using special equipment or machines.

a laboratory/dental technician

perceive.

to understand or think about something in a particular way.

Teachers perceive their roles in different ways.

fabulous.

extremely good.

You look fabulous.

thereby.

because of, or by means of, what has just been mentioned.

The diet makes the blood less sticky, thereby helping to prevent heart disease.

predator.

an animal that kills and eats other animals.

The birds have to be protected from foxes and other predators.

personnel.

the people who work for a company or organization, or who are members of a military force.

a change of personnel on the management team

rank.

someone’s official position in the military, police, fire department, etc..

Her rank when she retired was captain.

outcome.

the final result of a process, meeting, activity, etc..

A second game will be played to determine the outcome.

dismiss.

to refuse to accept that something might be true or important.

The senator dismissed claims that he had accepted bribes.

cultivate.

to make land suitable for growing crops or plants.

Most of the world’s fertile land is already being cultivated.

tobacco.

.

resemble.

to be similar to someone or something, especially in appearance.

The two species resemble each other.

acknowledge.

to accept or admit that something exists, is true, or is real.

He never acknowledges his mistakes  (=admits that he has made them).

sufficiently.

to the degree that is needed for a particular purpose.

Eventually the police felt they had a sufficiently large body of evidence.

allocate.

to officially give something to someone, or to decide that something can be used for a specific purpose.

Our task is to decide the best way to allocate scarce resources.

excluding.

used for saying that you are not including someone or something in what you are saying.

The average cost, excluding insurance, is around $600 a year.

scarce.

if something is scarce, there is not very much of it.

Fresh water and medicine were scarce in the disaster area.

inferior.

not as good as someone or something else.

It produces photographs of inferior quality.

vine.

the plant on which grapes grow.

vine leaves

hospitable.

generous toward visitors and guests.

a hospitable environment

indication.

a sign that something will happen, is true, or exists.

indication of: The size of the crowd is a clear indication of the strength of public feeling.

accustomed.

usual.

his accustomed seat

innovation.

a new idea, method, piece of equipment, etc..

the latest technological innovations

confidential.

confidential documents or information must be kept secret.

strictly/highly confidential: The reports are treated as strictly confidential.

grasp.

to take and hold something or someone very tightly.

She grasped his hand and pulled him toward her.

enforce.

to make sure that a law or rule is obeyed by people.

The main role of the police is to uphold and enforce the law.

discriminate.

to treat someone unfairly because of their religion, race, or other personal features.

Employers are not allowed to discriminate on the basis of gender.

minimal.

extremely small in amount or degree, or as small as possible.

If there is any delay, that delay will be minimal.

masculine.

with qualities thought to be typical of men.

a masculine voice

stroll.

to walk without hurrying, often for pleasure.

young couples out strolling with their arms around each other

bubble.

a ball of air or gas in a liquid.

Gas bubbles in any liquid tend to rise to the surface.

alert.

able to think in a clear and intelligent way.

He’s remarkably alert for his age.

stable.

not changing frequently and not likely to suddenly become worse.

People have become accustomed to a stable economic situation.

embrace.

to completely accept something such as a new belief, idea, or way of life.

Most countries have enthusiastically embraced the concept of high-speed railroads.

accelerate.

to happen or make something happen at a faster rate.

The increased capital could greatly accelerate economic development.

infrastructure.

.

feast.

a large meal.

a feast of wild raspberries

prominent.

important and well known.

The order was given by a prominent member of the government.

bankrupt.

a person or business that is bankrupt has officially admitted that they have no money and cannot pay what they owe.

bankrupt farmers

resume.

to start something again after stopping temporarily.

Shall we resume after lunch?

glimpse.

an occasion when you see someone or something for a moment only.

glimpse of: The crowd were anxious for a glimpse of the President.

linguistic.

relating to languages, words, or linguistics.

a child with poor linguistic skills

conservative.

not willing to accept much change, especially in the traditional values of society.

The small farming communities are predominantly conservative.

presume.

to think that something is true because it is likely, although you cannot be certain.

presume (that): I presume you’ve already ordered lunch.

alternate.

if one thing alternates with another, they happen or come one after another, in a regular pattern that keeps being repeated.

alternate with: Wet days alternated with dry ones.

initiative.

the ability to decide in an independent way what to do and when to do it.

Mr. Hills showed initiative and bravery when dealing with a dangerous situation.

boundary.

something such as a line on a map that marks where one area of land ends and another begins.

a proposal to redraw the city boundary to include more land for housing

complicate.

to make something more difficult to do, deal with, or understand.

Let’s not complicate matters by introducing any more restrictions.

splendid.

very impressive, or very good.

She is a splendid painter.

vague.

not clearly or fully explained.

Some aspects of the law were somewhat vague and ill-defined.

broadly.

something that is broadly accepted is accepted by most people in a general way, even if they do not agree about all the details.

The proposal was broadly welcomed by teachers.

enhance.

to improve something, or to make it more attractive or more valuable.

The measures taken should considerably enhance the residents’ quality of life.

inevitably.

used for saying that something is certain to happen.

Inevitably, reports of the failure were soon appearing in the newspapers.

administrative.

relating to the management of a company, organization, or institution.

purely administrative tasks

accessory.

a small thing such as a piece of jewelry or a pair of shoes that you wear with clothes to give them more style.

The book offers advice on choosing fabrics, furniture, and accessories.

noble.

behaving in an honest and brave way that other people admire.

a noble and courageous leader

sacred.

connected with religion.

a sacred holiday

compatible.

ideas or systems that are compatible can exist together.

compatible with: The proposed new regulation is not compatible with our existing policy.

deficiency.

a lack of something that your body needs.

anemia caused by iron deficiency

tolerant.

willing to accept someone else’s beliefs, way of life, etc. without criticizing them, even if you disagree with them.

a tolerant society

restrict.

to keep something within strict limits.

Travel is a dream of mine, but a busy working life has restricted my opportunities.

stereotype.

a very firm and simple idea about what a particular type of person or thing is like.

stereotype of: He certainly doesn’t fit the stereotype of the emotional Italian.

harsh.

harsh conditions or places are unpleasant and difficult to live in.

the harsh environment of the desert

inclusion.

the action of including someone or something in a group, arrangement, document, etc..

With the inclusion of Italy, the number of member countries increased to six.

tendency.

a strong chance that something will happen in a particular way.

a tendency (for someone/something) to do something: There’s a tendency for a new manager to make changes.

dominant.

more important, powerful, or successful than the other people or things of the same type.

The company cannot preserve its dominant position in the market.

phenomenon.

an event or situation that can be seen to happen or exist.

Violence in society is not a new phenomenon.

assert.

to state firmly that something is true.

He has continued to assert his innocence.

torture.

extreme physical pain caused by someone or something, especially as a punishment or as a way to make someone say something.

The confession was made under torture.

hatred.

a very strong feeling that you dislike someone or something very much.

hatred of: Some people have a hatred of anything new.

ally.

a country that makes an agreement with another country that they will work together to help each other, especially in a war.

the United States and its European allies

proportion.

a quantity of something that is a part or share of the whole.

proportion of: Only a small proportion of graduates fail to find employment.

purely.

completely, or as the only issue or reason.

What I’m saying is purely my own point of view.

quote.

to say or write words that someone else has said or written.

Can I quote you on that  (=repeat exactly what you have said about something)?

utterly.

completely: often used for emphasizing how bad someone or something is.

Young children are utterly dependent on their parents.

rehearse.

to practice a play, concert, opera, etc. before giving a performance.

We’ve been rehearsing for weeks.

excess.

a larger amount of something than is usual or necessary.

Cover both sides of the meat with flour, shaking off any excess.

rectify.

to correct a problem or mistake, or to make a bad situation better.

I am anxious to rectify this situation.

regulate.

to control an activity, process, or industry officially by using rules.

The proposal seeks to change the way the airline industry is regulated.

unload.

to take goods off a vehicle such as a truck or ship.

It was my job to unload the boxes from the van.

witch.

.

integrate.

to change the rules of a place, institution, or organization so that people of all races can enter it.

Laws were finally passed integrating all the restaurants.

restrain.

to prevent someone or yourself from doing something.

Please restrain yourself from coughing during the performance.

hygiene.

the practice of keeping yourself and the things around you clean, in order to prevent illness and disease.

personal hygiene

associate.

to form a connection in your mind between different people or things.

How do humans associate these seemingly opposed ideas?

modify.

to change something slightly, especially in order to improve it or to make it less extreme.

Under mandatory sentencing, the court has no authority to modify the prison term.

repetitive.

involving repeating the same action over long periods of time.

a boring repetitive job

sincere.

talking and acting in a way that shows you really mean what you say and do.

He is a modest and sincere man.

render.

to provide a service, or to give help to someone or something.

We are sincerely grateful to everyone who has rendered assistance to the victims of the earthquake.

tedious.

boring and continuing for too long.

a tedious job

logic.

the way that someone connects ideas when they are explaining something or giving a reason.

I don’t understand your logic.

cholesterol.

a substance that is found in the blood and the cells of the body. It can cause diseases of the heart and the arteries if there is too much of it.

There are many food products that claim to reduce cholesterol levels.

sheer.

used for emphasizing the amount or degree of something.

Maya succeeded through sheer hard work.

neutral.

a country that is neutral does not get involved in a war between other countries.

Russia promised to remain neutral unless Germany attacked France.

compile.

to make something such as a list or book by bringing together information from many different places.

The database was compiled from statistics published by the Tourist Board.

engage.

to attract and keep someone’s interest or attention.

A good radio script should be able to engage the listener.

commodity.

something that can be bought and sold, especially a basic food product or fuel.

Time is our most valuable commodity.

verify.

to check or to prove that something is true or correct.

There was no way to verify his claims.

equivalent.

with the same size, value, importance, or meaning as something else.

The price is $30,000, or the equivalent amount in euros.

gross.

a gross amount of money is the total amount before taxes or costs have been taken out.

a company with gross revenues of $50,000,000

intense.

very great or extreme.

He’s been under intense pressure.

commute.

to travel regularly to and from work.

I commute by train.
valueText: ev ile iş arasında gidip gelmek

keyText:
rational.

based on sensible practical reasons instead of emotions.

There didn’t seem to be any rational explanation for his actions.

starve.

to suffer or to die because there is not enough food.

There are people out there who are starving because of your actions.

similarly.

in a similar way.

Students in both schools achieved similarly low scores on the test.

optimist.

.

criteria.

.

conquer.

to take control of land or people using soldiers.

The tribes were easily conquered by the Persian armies.

dump.

to put something somewhere in a careless way, especially something that is heavy.

She dumped her bags on the floor and flopped onto the bed.

repeatedly.

many times.

We have repeatedly called for an official investigation into the affair.

erosion.

the process by which the surface of land or rock is gradually damaged by water, wind, etc. and begins to disappear.

soil/coastal/glacial erosion

jointly.

in a way that involves two or more people or groups sharing or doing something together.

The seminar is being organized jointly by the Canadian and Chilean governments.

arise.

if a particular situation or problem arises, it begins to exist or to develop.

Problems arose over plans to build a new supermarket here.

carriage.

a vehicle with wheels that is pulled by horses, especially one used in the past before cars were invented.

a typewriter carriage

guideline.

.

scare.

to make someone feel frightened or worried.

I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to scare you.

worship.

the activity of showing respect and love for a god, for example by singing or praying.

The building has been a place of worship since the eighth century.

urge.

to advise someone very strongly about what action or attitude they should take.

urge someone to do something: The United Nations has urged them to honor the peace treaty.

hostile.

behaving in a very unfriendly or threatening way toward someone.

The mayor found himself in the middle of a hostile crowd.

reinforce.

to make an idea, belief, or feeling stronger.

These latest figures reinforce the view that economic growth is slowing.

spectrum.

the whole range of ideas, qualities, situations, etc. that are possible.

the parties at the center of the political spectrum

solidarity.

the support that people in a group give each other because they have the same opinions or goals.

a need to create solidarity among the president’s top economic advisers

transaction.

the action or process of buying or selling something.

She had been involved in several suspicious transactions.

simplicity.

the quality of being simple.

the government’s wish to introduce simplicity into local government

slot.

a long narrow hole that you can fit something into.

He put a coin in the slot.

statistic.

a group of numbers that represent facts or that describe a situation.

New statistics show the economy is continuing to grow.

journal.

a magazine containing articles relating to a particular subject or profession.

a scientific journal

lawn.

an area of grass that is cut short, especially in someone’s yard.

mow/cut the lawn: The lawn needs mowing again.

impersonal.

not showing any friendly feelings or interest in someone.

His manner was cold and impersonal.

beak.

.

equation.

a statement that two sets of numbers, letters, or symbols are equal.

Solve the equation 5x – 3 = 27.

destiny.

the things that you will do, or the type of person that you will become, in the future.

Education can give you the power to shape your own destiny.

clarify.

to explain something more clearly so that it is easier to understand.

Could you clarify your remarks?

commonly.

usually or frequently.

the method most commonly used by researchers

overwhelm.

to affect someone’s emotions in a very powerful way.

We were overwhelmed by the sacrifices they had made.

distinct.

separate and different in a way that is clear.

They were classified into two distinct groups.

participant.

someone who takes part in something.

It was argued that he was a willing participant in the crime.

scholarship.

an amount of money that an organization gives to someone so that they can study at a particular school or university.

Sophie was awarded a scholarship to attend Boston University.

summit.

a meeting or series of meetings between leaders of two or more countries.

a summit of EU leaders

corrupt.

doing dishonest, illegal, or immoral things in order to gain money or power.

corrupt politicians/officials/judges

revenue.

income from business activities or taxes.

tax revenues

bulk.

something that is very large, wide, and solid.

She heaved her formidable bulk off the frail chair.

fake.

made to look like something real in order to trick people.

a fake passport/visa/document

exterior.

the outside part of something, especially a building.

There are plans to improve the hotel’s exterior.

emperor.

.

indirectly.

not in a direct, clear, or obvious way.

He was indirectly responsible for the deaths of five people.

provision.

the act of providing something that someone needs.

provision of: The Red Cross is in charge of the provision of emergency relief.

notorious.

famous for something bad.

a notorious criminal

counterpart.

someone or something that has the same job or purpose as another person or thing, but in a different country, time, situation, or organization.

The ambassador is meeting his German counterpart.

portable.

something that is portable is easy to carry or move, so that you can use it in different places.

Computers become lighter, smaller, and more portable every year.

comprise.

to consist of two or more things.

be comprised of: The course is comprised of two essays plus three assignments.

convey.

to communicate ideas or feelings indirectly.

These results will enable us at least to convey a sense of progress.

miner.

someone whose job is to dig coal, gold, etc. from the ground.

Miners rose as investors turned to riskier assets.

applause.

the sound made by people applauding a performance, speech, etc..

Her speech drew enthusiastic applause.

publicly.

in a way that many people notice.

Kent publicly disagreed with his fellow doctors on many occasions.

recruit.

to get someone to work in a company or join an organization.

We won’t be recruiting again until next year.

mundane.

ordinary and not interesting or exciting, especially because of happening too regularly.

mundane activities/tasks/matters

liable.

legally responsible for causing damage or injury, so that you have to pay something or be punished.

If something goes wrong, you’ll be liable.

extinct.

an extinct animal, plant, or language no longer exists.

The Tasmanian tiger was declared extinct in 1936.

component.

one of the different parts that a machine or piece of equipment consists of.

car components

fuss.

a lot of unnecessary worry or excitement about something.

What is all the fuss about?

unity.

a situation in which people, groups, or countries join together or agree about something.

The aim was to create an impression of party unity.

dumb.

stupid.

She’s so dumb she can’t even figure out her answering machine.

derive.

to receive or obtain something from something else.

be derived from something: products that are derived from animals

tuition.

money that you pay to take classes, especially at a college, university, or private school.

Tuition increased by 5% at state universities this year.

respective.

belonging separately to each of two or more people or things previously mentioned.

Jane and Patrick chatted about their respective childhoods.

hospitality.

friendly and generous behavior toward visitors and guests, intended to make them feel welcome.

We were delighted by the wonderful hospitality of the local people.

nap.

a short sleep, usually during the day.

take/have a nap: I think I’ll take a little nap this afternoon.

implication.

a possible effect or result.

implication of: We need to consider the financial implications of these changes.

surgeon.

.

beware.

used to warn someone of danger or difficulty.

Beware, buying a house is full of problems.

status.

the legal position of a person, country, etc..

Manuel applied for legal immigrant status after living here for two years.

restricted.

intended only for people who have been given special permission.

The officers were caught photographing in a restricted military zone.

innovative.

new, original, and advanced.

an innovative approach

ministry.

the profession or work of a church minister.

During his ministry he improved the church’s local image.

nutrition.

food considered as something that keeps you healthy.

adequate/poor nutrition

notify.

to inform someone officially about something.

Winners will be notified as soon as possible.

informative.

giving a great deal of information in a helpful way.

an entertaining and informative documentary

posture.

the position that your body is in when you sit, stand, or walk.

Exercise can improve your posture.

possess.

to own a physical object.

They were all found guilty of illegally possessing firearms.

trigger.

to make something happen.

The news of his death triggered more violence.

drawback.

a feature of something that makes it less useful than it could be.

drawback of/to: The main drawback of the scheme is its expense.

neglect.

to fail to take care of someone when you are responsible for them.

parents who neglect their children

worsen.

to become worse, or to make something worse.

The bill will worsen relations between Democrats and Republicans.

whatsoever.

used for emphasizing a negative statement.

no something whatsoever: It had no effect whatsoever.

affluent.

.

tactic.

a particular method or plan for achieving something.

The governor’s tactics involved accusing his opponent of being too liberal.

defect.

a fault in someone or something.

There are a few minor design defects.

shield.

.

impose.

to introduce something such as a new law or new system, and force people to accept it.

rules and regulations imposed by national governments

competence.

the ability to do something in a satisfactory or effective way.

He demonstrated thorough competence in dealing with the issues.

labour.

.

attain.

to succeed at achieving something, especially after much effort.

Not all athletes attain this standard of physical fitness.

perspective.

a way of thinking about something.

You can call it brave or foolish, depending on your perspective.

exhaust.

to make someone extremely tired and without energy.

Caring for young children can exhaust you physically and mentally.

assign.

to give someone a job to do.

be assigned to something: Two senior officers were assigned to the investigation.

twist.

to force something out of its original shape by bending it or turning it around.

The force of the explosion had twisted the metal.

inability.

the fact of not being able to do something.

inability to do something: He was frustrated by his inability to control the ball.

voluntary.

a voluntary action is done because you choose to do it, and not because you have to.

an attractive package to encourage voluntary early retirement

presently.

soon.

He’ll be with you presently.

subsidy.

an amount of money that the government or another organization pays to help to reduce the cost of a product or service.

The government pays subsidies to farmers to produce particular crops.

angle.

the shape that is made where two straight lines join or cross each other. Angles are measured in degrees. An angle that measures 90 degrees is a right angle; if it is less than 90 degrees, it is an acute angle, and if it is more than 90 degrees, it is an obtuse angle..

Guns were firing at them from several different angles.

burden.

a serious or difficult responsibility that you have to deal with.

Unemployment places a heavy burden on the welfare state.

solitude.

.

ultimately.

after a process or activity has ended.

Her efforts were ultimately bound to fail.

strip.

to take off all of your clothes or all of another person’s clothes.

They all stripped and ran into the water.

sacrifice.

to give up something important or valuable so that you or other people can do or have something else.

sacrifice something to do something: She sacrificed her career to bring up the children.

indirect.

not the immediate result of something.

an indirect approach to the problem

remarkably.

in a way that is unusual and surprises or impresses you.

Maria speaks remarkably good English.

sow.

to plant seeds in the ground.

Sow the seeds thinly outdoors in spring.

plunge.

to fall quickly from a high position.

It was still dark when the helicopter plunged 500 feet into the ocean.

drastic.

a drastic action or change has a very big effect.

Scientists have warned that cases of food poisoning will increase unless drastic action is taken.

imaginary.

not real but only created in your mind.

The Equator is just an imaginary line.

determine.

to officially decide something.

determine whether​/​why​/​who: It is for the court to determine whether she is guilty.

minimize.

to reduce something harmful or unpleasant to the smallest amount or degree.

We must minimize the damage to innocent civilians.

amid.

if something happens amid particular feelings or events, it happens while people have these feelings or while these events are happening.

Banks and stores closed yesterday amid growing fears of violence.

digest.

when your stomach digests food, it changes it into the substances that your body needs.

Cheese can be difficult to digest.

genius.

someone who is much more intelligent or skillful than other people.

Bach’s Magnificat is clearly the work of a genius.

cater.

to provide food and drinks at an event.

Who’s catering the party?

instruct.

to tell someone to do something, especially officially or as their employer.

instruct someone to do something: He instructed his men to collect information about troop movements.

resolve.

to make a formal decision, usually after a discussion and a vote at a meeting.

resolve to do something: The committee resolved to review the overall level of spending.

fright.

an experience that makes you feel suddenly afraid.

I got such a fright when Joe burst through the door.

thrill.

a sudden feeling of being very excited and pleased.

the thrill of (doing something): the thrill of visiting a new city

prolong.

to make something last longer.

The ongoing violence has prolonged the suffering of our people.

coal.

a hard black substance that is dug from the ground and burned as fuel to provide heat.

Put some more coal on the fire.

alarming.

frightening or worrying.

We are getting alarming reports of refugees being rounded up and shot.

sequence.

a set of related things that happen or are arranged in a particular order.

A computer can store and repeat sequences of instructions.

retail.

one of the first people to travel to a new country and start living there, especially one of the first Europeans to start living in North America.

pioneer of: the pioneers of early color photography

fertile.

fertile land is able to produce good crops or plants.

This is surely fertile ground for experimentation.

province.

one of many areas into which some countries are divided.

the Canadian provinces

rash.

an area of small red spots on your skin, caused by an illness or an allergic reaction to something that you have touched, eaten, etc..

diaper/poison ivy/heat rash

cargo.

things that are being sent by ship, airplane, train, or truck.

The ship and all its cargo sank.

horrified.

very shocked or frightened.

Police were horrified to discover a child’s body in the empty building.

blend.

to mix different foods or other substances together.

Blend the butter and the sugar together.

precede.

to happen or exist before another person or thing.

The paragraph that precedes this one is unclear.

retreat.

to avoid a dangerous, unpleasant, or embarrassing situation, especially by moving away from it.

The elephants retreated to the safety of the forest.

suppress.

to stop opposition or protest using military force or strict laws.

suppress a rebellion/uprising/demonstration: Pro-independence demonstrations were ruthlessly suppressed.

adolescent.

a boy or girl who is changing into a young man or woman. The physical changes that take place at this time are known as puberty. An adolescent between the ages of 13 and 19 is called a teenager.

Adolescents may need reassurance that their parents still love them.

virtue.

a good quality or habit that a person has, especially a moral one such as honesty or loyalty.

Patience is not one of my virtues.

underlying.

underlying causes, facts, ideas, etc. are the real or basic ones, although they are not obvious or directly stated.

The underlying causes of the riots have been ignored.

recur.

to happen again.

We must make sure that the problem does not recur.

courteous.

polite, especially in a formal way.

Hotel employees must be courteous at all times.

legacy.

money or property that you arrange for someone to have after you die.

My grandmother died and left me a small legacy.

intellect.

the ability to think in an intelligent way and to understand difficult or complicated ideas and subjects.

These activities are designed to develop a baby’s intellect.

dispute.

a serious disagreement, especially one between groups of people that lasts for a long time.

dispute between: a territorial dispute between rival gangs

optimism.

.

equate.

to consider something to be the same as something else.

equate something with/to something: These people seem to equate honesty with weakness.

negligible.

very unimportant or small.

a negligible rise in unemployment

unrest.

angry or violent behavior by people who are protesting against something.

The capital city is facing growing political unrest.

diagnose.

to find out what physical or mental problem someone has by examining them.

These questions help doctors diagnose personality disorders.

knot.

a point where string, rope, or cloth is tied together, or is twisted together and pulled tight.

Can you tie a knot in the end of this thread?

reconcile.

if you reconcile two people or groups, or if they reconcile, they become friendly again after a disagreement.

The couple has been making every effort to reconcile.

whereabouts.

the place where someone or something is: can be followed by a singular or plural verb.

someone’s/something’s whereabouts: The police have been investigating the group’s whereabouts.

echo.

if a noise echoes, it is repeated because the sound hits a surface and returns.

echo around/through: Her question echoed around the room.

formation.

the process during which something develops or is created.

the formation of stones in the kidneys

refine.

to remove things from a natural substance in order to make it pure.

We’ve refined the system since it was first launched.

spade.

.

suck.

to pull liquid into your mouth by using the muscles in your cheeks and tongue.

After the accident, I could only suck liquids through a straw.

incorporate.

to add or include something as a part of something else, for example as a part of an arrangement or a document.

incorporate something into/in something: Congress incorporated this principle into the 1977 clean-air Amendments.

arch.

a curved structure at the top of a door, window, or gate.

the arch above the front door

supplement.

to add something extra in order to improve something or make it bigger.

Heat from the chimneys is pumped back in to supplement the heating system.

cunning.

someone who is cunning uses their intelligence to get what they want, especially by tricking or cheating people.

a cunning and resourceful criminal

wary.

careful or nervous about someone or something because you think they might cause a problem.

He was wary of putting too much trust in her.

yield.

to produce something useful such as information or evidence.

Knowing about our past does not automatically yield solutions to our current problems.

refuge.

a place where you go to protect yourself from something dangerous or threatening.

a refuge for earthquake victims

tact.

.

rigid.

not easily changed.

a rigid class system

tenant.

someone who rents an apartment, house, office, piece of land, etc. from the person who owns it.

There are six commercial tenants in the building.

glow.

to shine with a soft light.

His desk light glowed in the darkness of the big room.

famine.

.

rot.

to decay by a gradual natural process, or to make something decay in this way.

All that candy will rot your teeth.

frontier.

a border between two countries, especially one with official points where people or vehicles cross.

frontier between: the frontier between Israel and Lebanon

recognition.

the ability to recognize a person or thing.

She looked at me without a flicker of recognition in her eyes.

dependence.

a situation in which you need someone or something in order to live or succeed.

dependence on: our dependence on our parents

stimulus.

anything that encourages something to happen, develop, or improve.

dedicate.

to spend your time and effort doing something.

dedicate something to something: Andy wants to dedicate more time to his hobbies.

tire.

the rubber cover of a wheel, that is filled with air.

a flat tire  (=a tire without air in it): Oh no! Not another flat tire!

frown.

to move your eyebrows down and closer together because you are annoyed, worried, or thinking hard.

Sarah frowned and shook her head.

excel.

to do something extremely well.

We aim to give every student the opportunity to excel.

erupt.

to start suddenly with a lot of violence or noise.

Police feared that a riot might erupt.

intent.

the intention to do something.

someone’s intent to do something: Congress has declared its intent to reform the welfare system.

defy.

to refuse to obey someone or something.

The commander defied a direct order to surrender.

prevail.

to be the strongest influence or element in a situation.

We hope that common sense will prevail and an agreement will soon be reached.

ponder.

to think carefully about something for a long time before reaching a decision.

Injuries to key players have left the coach pondering his options for the next game.

weary.

very tired, especially because of hard work or activity.

They collapsed on to their beds, too weary to get changed.

feeble.

physically weak, especially because you are old or sick.

a feeble light/voice

antibiotic.

.

instinct.

a natural tendency to behave in a particular way that people and animals are born with and that they obey without knowing why. For example the maternal instinct is a woman’s natural tendency to behave like a mother.

the instinct of ducklings to follow their mother

ritual.

a formal ceremony.

Their meetings became a weekly ritual.

consecutive.

following one after another in order and with nothing else in between.

He’s been late now on three consecutive days.

execute.

to kill someone as a punishment for a crime.

The state will execute him in 24 hours unless his appeal is granted.

integrity.

the quality of always behaving according to the moral principles that you believe in, so that people respect and trust you.

She had a reputation for honesty and personal integrity.

innate.

an innate quality or ability is one that you have always had.

His innate sense of justice made him popular with his workforce.

hail.

to say publicly how good or important someone or something is.

A familiar voice hailed him.

ignorance.

lack of knowledge or facts about a situation or a particular subject.

decisions based on ignorance and prejudice

stumble.

to fall or almost fall while you are walking or running.

civilian.

someone who does not belong to the military or the police.

crude.

made using very simple methods or materials.

assembly.

a part of a government consisting of people who have been elected to make laws.

ethics.

.

verge.

to almost be in a particular state.

adverse.

negative, unpleasant, or harmful.

sarcastic.

using sarcasm to upset someone or to show anger.

scrap.

a small piece of something such as paper or cloth.

scrap of: Messages were written on scraps of paper.

viable.

able to be done, or worth doing.

rhyme.

a short poem, often for children, that has lines ending in the same sound.

utter.

complete: often used for emphasizing how bad someone or something is.

bundle.

a group of things that have been tied together, especially so that you can carry them easily.

fluctuate.

to change frequently.

exclaim.

to say something suddenly and loudly, especially because you are surprised, impressed, angry, etc..

to officially order someone to come to a place, especially a court of law.

strive.

to make a lot of effort to achieve something.

proximity.

how near something is to another thing, especially in distance or time.

proximity to: the town’s proximity to the mountains

rally.

a public meeting that a lot of people go to in order to support someone or something or to protest against someone or something.

a pro-democracy rally

capitalism.

.

disclose.

to give information to people, especially information that was secret.

analogous.

similar to another situation, process, etc. so that the same things are true of or relevant to both.

overlap.

if two objects overlap, or if one overlaps the other, the edge of one fits over the edge of the other.

contemplate.

to consider doing something in the future.

refrain.

to stop yourself from doing something. This word is often used in official announcements or signs.

perception.

a particular way of understanding or thinking about something.

particle.

an extremely small piece or amount of something.

dust particles

subtle.

not obvious, and therefore difficult to notice.

timber.

.

pit.

a very large hole dug in the ground in order to obtain a particular substance or type of stone.

vicious.

a vicious attack/assault

medication.

a drug that you take to treat or cure an illness.

premium.

an amount of money that you pay regularly for an insurance policy.

sober.

fragile.

easy to break or damage.

mighty.

very large, powerful, or impressive.

pursuit.

the process of trying to achieve something.

spouse.

lure.

devise.

to invent a method of doing something.

immune.

safe from a disease, because you cannot be infected by it.

more of something than is necessary.

very detailed and complicated.

much smaller than things of the same kind.

to make something happen, especially something involving violence or angry feelings.

vivacious.

lively and attractive.

to ask for something in an urgent or emotional way.

a piece of cloth that you sew over a hole in clothes, or over a part where holes might form.

sorrow.

the body of a dead person.

the edge of a sidewalk  (=path built beside a road) that is closest to the road. The British word is kerb.

.
